utterance: Seigneur! qu'est-ce que c'est ?

utterance: Ma chère! how you frightened me!
speaker: the graduating class of 1874

utterance: Mon Dieu! I thought it was Monsieur Mignot!
speaker: the graduating class of 1874

utterance: I am trembling all over!
speaker: the graduating class of 1874

utterance: I can hardly stand up!
speaker: the graduating class of 1874

utterance: Just feel how my heart beats!
speaker: the graduating class of 1874

utterance: You had better hurry up, mes enfants,”
speaker: little girl

utterance: it is past eleven.
speaker: little girl

utterance: But we don't know one word,
speaker: the graduating class of 1874

utterance: not one single word.
speaker: the graduating class of 1874

utterance: Ah, bah! you are frightened, that's all; you always say that.
speaker: little girl

utterance:
I tell you, old Mignot is in a horrible temper.
Il a fait les quatre cents coups in our class; threw his inkstand at Stéphanie Morel's head.
speaker: the graduating class of 1874

utterance: Ah, je le savais bien

speaker: Jeanne

utterance: But I must come in with my basket.
speaker: woman outside

utterance: It is Mamzelle Marie's toilet for the exhibition.
speaker: woman outside

utterance: Don't you see I can't get in there?
speaker: woman outside

utterance: Ça m'est égal.
speaker: Jeanne

utterance: C'est un peu fort!
speaker: woman outside

utterance: Will you open the big gate for me so that I can bring in Mamzelle Marie's dress?
speaker: woman outside

utterance: Ristocrate !
speaker: Jeanne

utterance: Canaille!
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: Fait chaud mo dit toi
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: Marie Modeste, look at Marcélite
speaker: one of the girls

utterance: Chère!
speaker: little girls

utterance: Chérie!
speaker: little girls

utterance: Ange!
speaker: little girls

utterance: M'amie!

utterance: Là! mon bébé! là, ma mignonne! what do you think of that?
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance:
Just look at that! Ah ha! I thought you would be astonished! You see that lace?
Ça c'est du vrai, no doubt about that, Valenciennes. You think I don't know real lace, hein? and mousseline des Indes? You ask Madame Treize - you know what she said?
'Well, Marcélite, that is the prettiest pattern of lace and the finest piece of muslin I almost ever saw.' Madame Treize told me that herself; and it's true, for I know it myself.
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: Madame Treize, Marcélite?
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: Yes, Madame Treize. Who do you think was going to make your dress, hein? Madame N'importe-qui?
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: Marcélite, it must have cost so much!
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: Eh bien, it's all paid for. What have you got to do with that? All you have got to do is to put it on and wear it. Oh, mon bébé! ma petite chérie! if it had cost thousands and thousands of dollars it would not be too fine for you, nor too pretty.
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: But, Marcélite, I will be ashamed to wear it; it is too beautiful.
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance:
Here's the body! You see those bows?
That was my taste. I said to myself, 'She must have blue ribbon bows on the shoulder,' and I went back and made Madame Treize put them on. Oh, I know Madame Treize; and Madame Treize, she knows me!
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: And the shoes, Marcélite?
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance:
Now you see, Mamzelle, you always do that. Question, question, question, all the time.
Why didn't you wait? Now you have spoiled it all, all the surprise!
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: Pardon, Marcélite, I did not mean; but I was afraid you had forgotten —
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: Oh, mon bébé! when did Marcélite ever forget anything you wanted?
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: Ma bonne Marcélite! I am so impatient, I cannot help it.
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance:
White satin boots! Mar-cé-lite! White satin boots for me? Oh, I can't believe it!
And I expected black leather! - how shall I ever thank my uncle for them; and all this?
How can I ever do it?
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance:
Oh, but I know it was your idea, Marcélite!
My good, kind, dear Marcélite! I know it was all your idea. He never could have thought of all these beautiful things, -a man!
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: Ah, Marcélite, my uncle can never be as kind to me as you are. He gives me the money, but you —
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: Let us try them on
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: Too tight?
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: Too tight! just look!
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: I can change them if they are.
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: Do you want me to wear sabots like Jeanne?
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: They will stretch, anyhow.
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: I wonder what he will say, Marcélite?
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: Qui ça?
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: My uncle. Do you think he will be pleased ?
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: What makes you so foolish, bébé ?
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: But that's not foolish, Marcélite.
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: Hum!
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: Say, Marcélite, do you think he will be satisfied?
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: Satisfied with what?
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: Oh, you know, Marcélite, satisfied with me.
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: How can I tell, Mamzelle?
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: Mamzelle! Mamzelle! Madame Marcélite!
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: Well then, bébé.
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: Anyway, he will come to the concert Hein, Marcélite?
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: What is it, Zozo?
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: My uncle; he is coming to the concert, is n't he?
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: Ma bonne! do not be so mean; tell me if he is coming, and what he said.
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: Poor gentleman! he is so old.
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: Did he tell you that?
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance:
But, my child, what do you want him to say?
You bother me so with your questions, I don't know what I am doing.
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: But, Marcélite, it is only natural for me to want him to come to the concert and see me in my pretty dress that he gave me.
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: Well, when one is old and sick—
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: Sick! ah, you did not tell me that.
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: But I tell it to you all the time!
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: Oh, Marcélite !
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: So he is not coming to the concert?
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: Ah! there's the bell; you had better run quick before they send for you.
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance:
No, I am excused until time to practise my 37 duet.
Marcélite,
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: Marcélite, do you think my uncle will like me?
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: Mon Dieu! yes, yes, yes.
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: Mais ne t'impatiente pas, ma bonne, I can't help thinking about it. He has never seen me since I was a baby, I mean - and I don't recollect him at all, at all. Oh, Marcélite! I have tried so often, so often to recall him, and my maman
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance:
If I could only go just one little point farther back, just that little bit she measured off a demicentimetre on her finger-but impossible.
Maybe it will all come back to me when I see him, and the house, and the furniture. Perhaps if I had been allowed to see it only once or twice, I might be able to remember something.
It is hard, Marcélite, it is very hard not even to be able to recollect a mother. To-morrow evening!
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: One reason I want him to come to the concert is to take me home with him. In the first place, Madame would n't let me go unless he came for me; and — and I want the girls to see him; they have teased me so much about him. I believe, Marcélite, that if my graduating were put off one day longer, or if my uncle did not come for me to-morrow evening, I would die. How foolish! Just think of all these years I have been here, summer after summer, the only boarder left during vacation! I. did n't seem to mind it then, but now it's all different; everything has become so different this last year.
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance:
Crying, mon bébé? What is the matter with you - oh, oh!
do not feel well! something you do not like about your toilette, hein?
Tell Marcélite, chérie; tell your bonne. There!
there!
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: Is Marie Modeste here?
speaker: little voice

utterance: Yes.
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: They want you for the Cheval de Bronze.
speaker: little voice

utterance:
Thank you, Marcélite. Thank you for everything for my beautiful dress, and my shoes; and thank my uncle too, and try and persuade him to come to-morrow evening, won't you, Marcélite? Do not tell him about my crying, though. Oh, I want to go home so much, and to see him!
You know if you want you can get him to come. Won't you promise me, ma bonne?
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: You know I would kill myself for you, mon bébé.
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: The concours was very difficult, chère?
speaker: Paula

utterance: Yes, very difficult.
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: And Monsieur Mignot is so trying. I think he gets more exigeant every day.
speaker: Paula

utterance: Grand Dieu Seigneur! What am I going to do now! I believe I am turning fool!
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: Ah! c'est toi, Marcélite!
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: Eh, bien, qu'en dis-tu, Marcélite?
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance:
Pauvre petite chatte! I shall miss her very much; you know, Marcélite, it seems only a year or two since you brought her here a little baby, and now she is a young lady of seventeen. Thirteen years ago! What a chétive little thing she was! You were as much of a scholar here then as she; you had to stay with her so much. You have been a faithful nurse to her, ma bonne femme. A mother could not have been more devoted, and very few would have done all you have for that child. Ah! that's a thing money can never pay for, - love. I hope Marie will always remember what you have been to her, and repay it with affection.
But she will; she is a good girl, a good, good girl, pauvre petite! It is Monsieur Motte, though, who should give you a handsome present, something really valuable. I would like to know what he would have done for a bonne for his niece without you. You remember that summer when she had the fever? Eh, well, she would have died but for you; I shall never forget her sad little face and her big black 53 eyes. You know, her mother must see all that; I can never believe, Marcélite, that a mother cannot come back, sometimes, to see her children, particularly a little girl –
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: She was always such a quiet little thing, ma foi! I used to forget her entirely; but now she is going away, I know I shall miss her, yes, very much. I hope the world will be kind to her. She will be handsome, too, some day, when she does not have to study so hard, and can enjoy the diversions of society a little. By the time she is twenty you will see she will be une belle femme. Ah, Monsieur Motte, you will be satisfied, allez!
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: Mamzelle Marie, too, she will be sorry to leave Madame.
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: Oh no, girls are always glad to quit school. Very naturally, too. When one is young, one does not like to stay indoors and study, when there is so much outside, dancing, music, beaux.
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: It is all past for me now, but I can recollect how I felt when I was seventeen. Apropos, Marcélite, did you give my invitation to Monsieur Motte?
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: Yes, Madame.
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: And what did he say?
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: He he sent his compliments to Madame.
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: Yes; but did he say he would come to 55 the concert? I wanted particularly to know that.
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: He is so old, Madame.
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: Là, là, the same old excuse! I am so tired of it.
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: But when one is old, Madame.
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: Ah, bah! I do not believe he is too old for his own pleasure. I know men; old age is a very convenient excuse at times.
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance:
But this time he must come, par exemple!
even if he is so old. I think he might subject himself to some little inconvenience and trouble to see his niece graduate. He has not put himself out much about her for twelve or thirteen years.
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: God knows! Madame.
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: God knows? Mais, Marcélite, how silly you talk! Don't you see that Monsieur Motte must come to-morrow night, at least to take Marie home? God does know, and so should he.
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: Perhaps he wants Miss Marie to stay another year, Madame; you see, she is so young, and-and-there is so much to learn, enfin.
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance:
He wants that, does he? he wants that! Ah, l'égoïste! That is like a man; oh, I know them, like a b c. No, if Marie is not too young to graduate, she is not too young to leave school; and besides, if she had not learned everything, how could she graduate? There is an end to learning, enfin. You tell Monsieur Motte that.
But no, tiens, it is better I shall write it.
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance:
I hope he will be kind to her, and look out for a good parti for her. Of course she will have a dot, his only relative. Did you not tell me she was his only relative, Marcélite?
He has absolutely no one else besides her?
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: No, Madame.
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: Well, then, she will get it all when he dies, unless" - with a shrug—“I do not know; one is never sure about men.
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: Nearly three o'clock! I must go and make my tour. Au revoir, ma bonne. Be sure and give Monsieur Motte my note, and come early to-morrow morning; and do not forget to think about what I told you, you know.
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: Ah, mon Dieu, ayez pitié de moi, pauvre négresse!
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: C'est bon; tell Marcélite to come as soon as she is ready.
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: Mais, come in donc, Marcélite!
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: You are a little early this morning, it seems.
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: It is not Marcélite; it is I, Madame Joubert.
speaker: Madame Joubert

utterance: You! Madame Joubert!
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: I thought it was Marcélite.
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: No, it is I.
speaker: Madame Joubert

utterance: But what is the matter, Madame Joubert?
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: It is twelve o'clock, Madame.
speaker: Madame Joubert

utterance: Twelve o'clock! Impossible!
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: You hear it ringing, Madame.
speaker: Madame Joubert

utterance: But where is Marcélite?
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: Marcélite did not come this morning.
speaker: Madame Joubert

utterance: Marcélite did not come this morning!
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: How should I know, Madame?
speaker: Madame Joubert

utterance: She must be ill; send Jeanne to see.
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: I did that, Madame, five hours ago; she was not in her room.
speaker: Madame Joubert

utterance: But what can have become of her?
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: I cannot imagine, Madame.
speaker: Madame Joubert

utterance: But I must have some one to comb my hair.
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance:
The music-teacher is waiting for you. The French professor says he will be here again in a half-hour; he has been here twice already.
Madame Criard says that it is indispensable for her to consult you about the choruses.
speaker: Madame Joubert

utterance: Mais, mon Dieu! Madame Joubert, I must have a hairdresser!
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: The girls are all very tired; they say they will be worn out by to-night if they are kept much longer. They have been up ever since six o'clock.
speaker: Madame Joubert

utterance:
I know, I know, Madame Joubert; it was an accident. I also was awake at six o'clock. F'ai fait la nuit blanche. Then I fell asleep again.
Ah! that miserable Marcélite! I beg of you, tell Jeanne to go for some one, no matter whom - Henriette, Julie, Artémise. I shall be ready in a moment.
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: Madame, said Jeanne at the door, I have been everywhere. I cannot find a hairdresser at home; I have left word at several places, and Madame Joubert says they are waiting for you.
speaker: Jeanne

utterance: Madame, said a little girl, trying to speak distinctly, despite a nervous shortness of breath, Madame Joubert sent me to tell you they were waiting.
speaker: little girl

utterance: Very well, mon enfant, very well. I am coming.
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: Madame Joubert vous fait dire,
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Tell Madame Joubert I am coming in a moment.
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: Mais ce n'est pas mal, en effet,
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: I suppose Marcélite will be sure to come this evening?
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: Oh, that is sure, Madame,
speaker: Madame Joubert

utterance: What will you do when you quit school, Marie?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Ah, you know that depends entirely upon my uncle,
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: How is le vieux to-day?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Give my love to le vieux.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Dis donc, why does n't le vieux take Marie away in the summer?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Did you see the beautiful étrennes le vieux has sent Marie?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: They say he has sent her a superb toilette for the exhibition, made at Madame Treize's, and white satin boots.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Just look at my head, I ask you!
speaker: unspecified

utterance: But mine is worse than yours.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: I shall never be able to do anything with mine.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: The more I brush, the more like a nègre I look.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Ah, Marie, how wise you were not to put your hair in papillotes!
speaker: unspecified

utterance: And all that trouble for nothing, hein!
speaker: unspecified

utterance: And the pain.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: I did n't sleep a wink last night.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: See how nice Marie looks with her hair smoothly plaited.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: I will never forgive Marcélite.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Nor I.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Nor I.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Nor I.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Oh, my bébé ! my little mistress! it's your nurse, it's your own negro who loves you, who would die for you!
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance:
Frankly, he will kill us all, that old man! I can never forgive him for not having lived; but it is in accordance with his character. What a monster of selfishness! I have been thinking, -ah, you do not know what my life is here with those two, Marie and Marcélite ! — I have been thinking that perhaps I would accept Aurore Angely's invitation. She writes me every year to come on a visit to her plantation for a month or two. What do you say, eh? There is only one objection, it is in the country. If it were only in the city; but the country,—dame!
I have always held the country in horror. It is years since I have seen Aurore and Félix.
Ah! he is a torpedo for you! exploding at a touch. Poor little thing! She has never been to the country, never even seen it!
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: I should hope not, Madame!
speaker: Monsieur Goupilleau

utterance: God knows best; when he wishes to put the finishing, the perfecting touch to a woman, he simply sends her in youth some misfortune. It is his way; and I for one, have nothing to criticise, seeing the results;
speaker: Monsieur Goupilleau

utterance: Yes, I think we can take the Saturday boat; you know the boats leave every Saturday evening. And now, I must go immediately and inform Madame Joubert. To tell you the truth, my friend, I do not think I could endure Madame Joubert all the summer. She is of a rigidity, a rigidity!
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: But do not go; I shall return in a moment. I have something else to consult you about, you are so kind!
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: Ah, mon Dieu! les hommes ! les hommes!
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance:
Send Edmond to me.
Tell Joe to get ready to take the next boat to the city. I thought you were going to hunt up that roll of wire in the store-room. Has n't old Simon sent yet?
Don't forget to copy Smith's estimate.
Go to the sugar-house-no; I shall tell Duval myself to go to the devil with his charges. Don't 123 forget about the lamp-wicks and the towels for the sugar-house, and oh, yes, tell Stasie to — fetch me some ink; it is very strange that the inkstand is never filled unless I see about it myself — and Aurore!
speaker: Félix

utterance: Yes, Féfé.
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance: The key of the medicine chest!
speaker: Félix

utterance: Misère! Misère!
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance: Bon-soir, Eugénie.
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance: Bon-soir, Aurore.
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance:
Ma chère, I feel like a pagan, leaving you so much alone; but Féfé, - you cannot imagine what he is! What makes men such devils when they are sick? If Féfé would only be sensible and have a physician and get well; but no, he and Stasie think they can cure anything. Physician! he would as soon see a priest, and priests are his bêtes-noires. How can an intelligent man be so prejudiced? But it is the way he was educated; that comes of sending boys to France to be educated; that is the teaching of Messieurs Voltaire and Rousseau.
Oh, I compliment them!
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance: Fancy, Eugénie, after all the trouble I took to explain to him this morning, he brings the mail-bag devoured by hogs, all the letters a disgusting mass. Only one could I extricate entire for Féfé. I don't speak of your letters
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance: Oh, you know very well I never get letters from any one but Madame Joubert; always the same school news. The swine are welcome.
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance:
I wish Féfé were so reasonable.
And he will say you know what reason he will 125 give for it all-religion; too much Mass. He will say he expected it before, and I shall never hear the end of it. Now, we, because Gabi was pious, and really, Eugénie, at times in church I have watched him, he had moments of genuine fervor, we would say that his religion was a reason why he should bring the mail well and be a good servant; but not Féfé, he is so prejudiced. It prevents everything.
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance: Mamzelle, Monsieur Félix asks if you have forgotten the key of the medicine chest?
speaker: Stasie

utterance: Ah! la, la!
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance: Mamzelle, Monsieur Félix asks
speaker: Stasie

utterance: I hear, Stasie, I hear.
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance: Ah, yes, my key-basket, — I have left it somewhere; but where can I have left it?
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance: It is impossible, Mamzelle, to hear one word you are saying.
speaker: Stasie

utterance: I was only talking to myself, Stasie.
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance: Plait-il?
speaker: Stasie

utterance: Nothing, Stasie, nothing.
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance: If I only had a friend, an adviser; ah! a woman ought never to be without one, in fact.
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: Love! what! she believes in it still? Elle en veut, encore! what innocence, hein?
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: But is a woman's heart a thermometer to be regulated according to outside appearances?
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: Ah! if pauvre maman were here!
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: If she were here, she would decide for me!
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: Aïe, Marcélite! the horn! I shall be late again for supper.
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: Ma chère ! you will scarcely believe it; I can hardly recover from the surprise myself. Talk of changes; that's a change. Fefé will actually have to send to the city this roulaison for Italians, Italians! Italians to take off the crops; if poor papa could see that!
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance:
But, Stasie, give Mademoiselle 139 Marie some fricassée, fricassée! fricassée! That is what competition does, - negroes running from place to place to get five cents more pay; and it all comes from that old Simon and Mr.
Smith. What more can you expect? They do not care; they have no sentiment. A plantation is a sugar factory to them, that is all. The idea that such canaille should be allowed to profit by the ruin of our old families, and buy up the finest places in Louisiana! Oh, they can afford to offer more to negroes than others, and force us to hire Italians! Old Sîmon: Stasie can tell you who old Sîmon is; you ought to hear Stasie talk about him. She remembers the day well when he used to go up and down the coast with a pack on his back, crying Rabais, and selling things to the negroes; it is only right that he should pay them well now, he made them pay enough, vas!
and now he owns La Trinité. And Mr. Smith, tiens! Eugénie, you remember Nathalie Cortez at school; you know when she graduated!
Well, her daughter has just been married to this Mr. Smith. Don't repeat it as coming from me, you know, but, his father was a negro trader, a negro trader, my dear! absolutely a man Nathalie would not have permitted to sit at the table with her.
Stasie knows; you ask Stasie. That's what poverty does.
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance: I cannot hear a word you say, Mamzelle. If you would only speak a little more distinctly, instead of getting excited.
speaker: Stasie

utterance: The pain-perdu! pain-perdu!
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance:
And Féfé, he exasperates me so!
Whatever old Simon or Mr. Smith gets, Féfé thinks he must buy too, vacuum-pans, condensers, steam-trains, bagasse-burners, a perfect 'galimatias' of machinery. As if gentlemen needed all that; and as if they had not been making sugar long enough in Louisiana without it! For my part, I like the old open kettles, and I prefer the sugar, too, though it was not so white, and Stasie, she prefers it too. In poor papa's time it was all so different; but Félix has his own ideas. He loves everything modern and new; he is all for the practical. The house 141 and garden might just as well be in Texas, for all he cares about them; and then, after all, if old Simon or Mr. Smith makes sugar a little whiter than ours, or sells it a little bit higher, oh, then it is Good Friday the rest of the winter! But, 'Mon cher,' I tell him, 'think who they are.'
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance: Monsieur Félix asks Mamzelle to come there just one moment.
speaker: Edmond

utterance: Oh, I know what it is, it is that estimate I forgot to copy. Sans excuses, chérie; you see how it is.
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance: Bébé!
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: Bébé!
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: Paix, Marcélite, paix.
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: You will catch cold.
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance:
Ah, Marcélite! why could you not have left me one moment more?
Now
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: Bébé, you will catch cold, or fever, the air is so bad at this season.
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: There, I hope you are satisfied now!
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance:
If Marcélite would only let her alone!
The moonlight was so beautiful, and at school they never enjoyed the moonlight except in contraband. In a week she would be back at school. Why could not Marcélite let her forget that; it was so seldom she could forget it!
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: Tiens, voilà Marie Modeste, back again at school! mais, chère, is le vieux going to make you stay another year? Quelle injustice!
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: Ah! you know, it is a romance, - all a romance of Marcélite's. My papa, he was killed during the war, my mamma, she died when I was a baby, and Marcélite - just fancy, 147 chère, that good Marcélite - worked for me night and day, to send me to school; she it was who gave me everything.
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: I shall go to bed; come, Marcélite.
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: Bonne-nuit, ma mignonne; going to Mass again to-morrow morning?
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: You are happy, ma fille?
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: I, Madame? happy!
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: But, of course, Marie is going to Mass with me to-morrow.
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance: Is anything the matter with you, bébé ?
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: Nothing, Marcélite.
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: You are sure you feel well?
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: Oh yes, I feel well.
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: Let me get you a glass of sirup and water.
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: No, thank you, Marcélite.
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: Did you hear about that little rascal Gabi?
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: Yes.
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: Edmond should give him a good whipping; the idea of Mademoiselle Aurore hiding him in her room! She spoils him until he is perfectly good for nothing.
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: You like it here on the plantation, bébé ?
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: You think perhaps I prefer boarding-school?
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance:
Ah, but wait till you see the grinding! That is the grand time of the year on a plantation!
Some night, soon, a frost will come; in the gray daylight it will look like flour sprinkled all over the cane; then, when it gets lighter, it looks like silver; when the sun gets on it, it is diamonds, diamonds scattered everywhere. Then you hear the cane-knives, cling! clang! cling!
clang! and the cane falling, fron! fron! fron!
fron! One cut at the top, one cut at the roots, over it goes! Each hand takes a row; I tell the women are not behind the men then!
I have seen them keep up, step by step, twenty rows at a time! A field soon gets flat and bare at that rate; then the carts coming and going, dumping their loads in the shed, the sugarmill with all steam up; and the cane-carrier, you
- you will hear them sing at the cane-carrier!
You never heard singing like that, all day, all night.
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: That will be fine, eh, bébé ?
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance:
The river ran in front of the old plantation, just as it does here. And the orange-trees went in long rows to the levee. The flower-garden was here, the fields over there, and the quarters on this side, indicating the localities by gesture. But it was finer, grander. Ah, the Motte plantation was celebrated, I tell you, all up and down the The quarters were like a street in the city, the sugar-house looked as big as the custom-house. The largest boats on the river would stop at our levee for the sugar and molasses.
The dwelling-house was twice the size of this, and the furniture, four, five, ten times handsomer. The armoires were filled with laces and silks and feathers left by the mamans, grandmamans, the aunts and cousins who were dead and gone. There were pictures all over the walls, like here, only Mottes and Viels; and this, pointing to a framed escutcheon, “ was on everything, silver, china, glass-
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance: Good-night, ma bonne; I am afraid Madame may need you.
speaker: Marie Modeste Motte

utterance: Bébé, it was your home! Why don't you listen? Why don't you believe me? Do you think I would lie to you about that?
speaker: Marcélite Gaulois

utterance:
Oh, chère amie! I get very much discouraged with life, I assure you; it takes a great deal of religion to enable us women to support it. It is so full of contradictions, useless contradictions. I sometimes wish that there were no more hopes given us. They are no better than toy balloons; they dance before us very beautifully for a time, then crac!
they burst, and we are left plantées there until 157 we get another one. I do not complain, it is against my religion; but if you knew how many hopes I have seen go to pieces that way! Mon Dieu! I am tired of getting new ones. Ah, you are fortunate, your life is so simple, so clear, so smooth. Now, there's Gabi, I should not have sent him; ah! I see that clearly this morning.
But I have raised that child ever since he was a baby. He was picked up in the sugar-house and brought to me. I have no idea even who his mother is. Well, I thought I would take him and make a reasonable human being of him. Féfé and Stasie were against it, of course; they have never liked him. I wanted to push him; I thought I would give him the opportunity. Well, perhaps Féfé is right, after all.
And he learned his Catechism so well, and made such a good first communion! Last spring, you know what I did? I got all the children of the proper age in the quarters, I taught them the Catechism myself, and I made them all make their first communion; there was a cane-cart full. Féfé and Stasie were against that too, but I was firm. Ah, it is so elevating to work like that! Féfé, he said they were rascals already, and that I would only make hypocrites of them.
Hypocrites! I ask you, Eugénie, if religion makes hypocrites? But that is Monsieur Voltaire again. I will never hear the last of this from Stasie, and next spring Féfé will only be more determined; I know Féfé.
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance:
Yes, our lives are surprise-boxes to us women; we never know what is going to come out of them: our own plans, our own ideas count for nothing. Look at our schoolmates: not one turned out as she expected. Those who had a vocation to religious lives, who would be nothing but nuns, they were the first ones married and having children christened. Those who were ready to fall in love with every new tenor at the opera, they became dévotes. Those who cared only for money fell in love with poor men; and those who made their lives a poem, with love 159 for the hero, they, they married for money.
When we are old and passées, we get what would have made our youth divine. Men are the serious occupation, women are the playthings, of fate.
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: Ah, yes, men are more fortunate.
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance: There is something sure, something stable in a man's life. Look at Féfé. I do not say he has not had griefs, disappointments, misfortunes even, in his life, but they did not change it, only interrupted it a minute; with me, those things take away my life itself. It is like this: either Féfé would not have sent Gabi for the mail, or Gabi would have brought it properly, or he would have informed the whole world about it, me first of all, coûte que coûte. He would not have managed the truth on account of my prejudices, he would have had no hopes attached to it; now with me
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance: But, Eugénie, what can that be?
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance: How it frightened me! It must be some one knocking.
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance:
Some one knocking at the front door?
Impossible!
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance: Some one, perhaps, to see Monsieur Félix.
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: Félix? But his visitors all know they have to go around to the other gallery. There it is again!
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance: Maybe it is some one who does not know.
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: I will call Stasie.
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance: But let us see who it is.
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: Not for the world! It might be something horrible out there.
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance: Go, ma bonne Stasie. It must be some one to see Monsieur Félix; conduct him around to the other side of the house.
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance: But what are you doing, Stasie?
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance: What do you think? That sotte Stasie has actually opened the front door, and there is a stranger, at this moment, in the hall. But no; impossible!
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance: Mamzelle,
speaker: Stasie

utterance: Well, Stasie, I compliment you! Letting a stranger into the house this way!
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance:
What do you mean by opening the house.
this way? Are you crazy?
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance: He is a gentleman - a visitor.
speaker: Stasie

utterance: Comment donc? Would you have me shut the door in his face? Would you have me drive him away-a gentleman — when he comes on a visit?
speaker: Stasie

utterance:
What nonsense!
A visitor!
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance: What! You are undressing, Eugénie?
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance: Only changing my peignoir, Aurore. The air seems a little cool to me.
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance: You must understand, Stasie, there is some mistake. If he does not come to see Monsieur Félix on business, he must be going to old Simon's or Mr. Smith's. Go and explain to him- although you should have told him on the gallery, not brought him into the house.
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance: There, Mamzelle, there; see for yourself!
speaker: Stasie

utterance: Ah, I told you so! Shut the door in his face! Put him out by the shoulders! Ah, that was not the etiquette of your grandmother, par exemple!
speaker: Stasie

utterance: Mais qu'est-ce que c'est que ça? I cannot understand it. Monsieur-
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance: My négligé from Paris,
speaker: Madame Lareveillère

utterance:
Monsieur Armand Goupilleau. Goupilleau?
Goupilleau? But I never heard of a Goupilleau.
And you, Eugénie?
speaker: Mademoiselle Angely

utterance: Monsieur Armand Goupilleau? Surely I know Monsieur Armand Goupilleau. He is a notary public in New Orleans oh, but one of the most celebrated notaries there! He is f
